natural solution: We can superimpose the graph of $y=x$ on the graph of $y=f(x)$: [asy] size(150); real ticklen=3; real tickspace=2; real ticklength=0.1cm; real axisarrowsize=0.14cm; pen axispen=black+1.3bp; real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm;

real tickdown=-0.5; real tickdownlength=-0.15inch; real tickdownbase=0.3; real wholetickdown=tickdown; void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {

import graph; real i; if(complexplane) { label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE); label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW); } else { label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5)); label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2)); } ylimits(ybottom,ytop);

xlimits( xleft, xright); real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry; for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArrx.push(i); } } for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArry.push(i);

} } if(usegrid) { xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true); yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);

} if(useticks) { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));

} else { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); } }; rr_cartesian_axes(-3,3,-3,3);

dot((-2,-3),red,UnFill); dot((-1,-2),red,UnFill); dot((0,-1),red,UnFill); dot((1,0),red,UnFill); dot((2,1),red,UnFill); dot((3,2),red,UnFill); [/asy] Then $|f(a)-a|$ is the vertical distance from the green to the red graph at $x=a$.

We can see that this distance varies from $0$ to $1$, inclusive of $0$ but not of $1$ (since the hollow dots on the graph of $y=f(x)$ represent points which are not part of the graph). Since $f(x)\le x$ for all $x$, we see that $f(x)-x$ is zero or negative, and its range is $\boxed{(-1,0]}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (-3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> y. y = f x - x \<and> -1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 0)"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. f x - x) = {-1 .. 0}"
a_0.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x)$ such that for all $x$ in the interval $[-3, 3]$, there exists a $y$ such that $y = f(x) - x$ and $-1 \le y \le 0$. Show that the range of the function $g(x) = f(x) - x$ is the closed interval $[-1, 0]$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> (f x) - x \<in> {-1..0}"
shows  "range (\<lambda> x. (f x) - x) = {-1..0}"
a_1.informal problem: For a real-valued function f, if for all real x between -3 and 3, the value of f(x) - x is between -1 and 0, inclusive, then prove that the range of f(x) - x is {-1, 0}.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> y x = f x - x"
shows  "\<forall> x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> -1 \<le> y x \<and> y x \<le> 0"
a_2.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$ between $-3$ and $3$, let $y(x)$ be defined as $f(x) - x$. Show that for all $x$ in the same range, $y(x)$ is between $-1$ and $0$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f(x) = x"
shows  "f x - x \<in> {-1..0}"
a_3.informal problem: Given a function $f$, defined such that for all $x$ in the range $-3 \leq x \leq 3$, $f(x) = x$. Prove that the difference $f(x) - x$ is in the interval $[-1, 0]$.

a_4.formal problem:
lemma range_of_function:
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f x = x"
shows  "\<exists>a b. a \<le> b \<and> {f x - x | x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3} = {y. a < y \<and> y \<le> b}"
a_4.informal problem: For a function $f(x) = x$ that is defined in the interval from -3 to 3, find the range of the function. There exist values $a$ and $b$ such that $a$ is less than or equal to $b$ and the set of all differences between $f(x)$ and $x$ for $x$ in the interval from -3 to 3 is equal to the set of all $y$ such that $y$ is strictly greater than $a$ and less than or equal to $b$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f x = x + 1"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. f x - x) = {-1..0}"
a_5.informal problem: For a function $f(x)$ defined on the interval $[-3, 3]$, if $f(x) = x + 1$, what is the range of the function $f(x) - x$? The final answer is the interval $[-1, 0]$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "-3 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 3"
and h2 : "f x - x \<in> {-1..0}"
shows  "f x - x \<in> {-1..0}"
a_6.informal problem: Let $f(x)$ be a function defined on the interval $-3 \leq x \leq 3$ such that $f(x) - x$ is in the range $[-1, 0]$. Show that for any $x$ in the given interval, $f(x) - x$ is indeed in the range $[-1, 0]$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>y. f x = y)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f(x) - x \<in> {-1..0}"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. f(x) - x) = {-1..0}"
a_7.informal problem: Given a function $f(x)$ that is defined for all $x$ in the range $-3 \le x \le 3$, and for every $x$ in that range, $f(x) - x$ is in the range $-1 \le f(x) - x \le 0$. Show that the range of the function $g(x) = f(x) - x$ is exactly the interval $[-1, 0]$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f x = x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f (x - 1) = x - 1"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. f x - x) = {-1 .. 0}"
a_8.informal problem: Given a function $f(x)$ such that for all $x$ in the range $[-3, 3]$, $f(x) = x$ and $f(x - 1) = x - 1$, find the range of the function $g(x) = f(x) - x$. The final answer is the range of $g(x)$ is $[-1, 0]$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>y. y = f x \<and> -3 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. -3 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> f x - x \<in> {y. -1 < y \<and> y \<le> 0}"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. f x - x) = {y. -1 < y \<and> y \<le> 0}"
a_9.informal problem: Given a function $f(x)$, for all $x$ in the range $[-3, 3]$, there exists a $y$ such that $-3 \leq y \leq 3$ and $f(x) - x$ is in the range $(-1, 0]$. Show that the range of the function $g(x) = f(x) - x$ is $(-1, 0]$.
